object: The Battle of the Hydaspes was fought between Alexander the Great and Porus in May of 326 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Mallian_campaign
object: The Mallian campaign was conducted by Alexander the Great from November 326 to February 325 BC, against the Malli of the Punjab.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sogdian_Rock
object: The Sogdian Rock or Rock of Ariamazes, a fortress located north of Bactria in Sogdiana, ruled by Arimazes, was captured by the forces of Alexander the Great in the early spring of 327 BC as part of his conquest of the Achaemenid Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: On the left bank of the Hydaspes, Alexander fights his last great battle, the Battle of the Hydaspes River. He and his general Craterus defeat the Indian King Porus. Alexander founds two cities there, Alexandria on the Indus or Alexandria Nicaea (to celebrate his victory) and Alexandria Bucephalous or Bucephala (named after his horse Bucephalus, which dies there); and Porus becomes his friend and ally.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Indian_campaign_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: The Indian campaign of Alexander the Great began in 327BC and lasted until 325BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander continues on to conquer all the headwaters of the Indus River. East of Porus' kingdom, near the Ganges River, Alexander faces the powerful empire of Magadha ruled by the Nanda dynasty. Fearing the prospects of facing another powerful Indian army and exhausted by years of campaigning, his army mutinies at the Hyphasis River (the modern Beas River) and refuses to march further east, thus making this river mark the easternmost extent of Alexander's conquests.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Cophen_campaign
object: The Cophen campaign was conducted by Alexander the Great in the Kabul Valley between May 327 BC and March 326 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Cyropolis
object: Cyropolis was the largest of seven towns in the region that Alexander the Great targeted for conquest in 329 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander attacks Oxyartes and the remaining Bactrian barons who are holding out in the hills of Paraetacene (modern Tajikistan). The Macedonians seize the crag on which Oxyartes has his stronghold (the Sogdian Rock), and among the captives is his daughter, Roxana. In the reconciliation that follows the battle, Alexander marries Roxana. The rest of Oxyartes' opponents are either won over or crushed.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Jaxartes
object: The Battle of Jaxartes was fought in 329 BC by Alexander the Great and his Hellenic army against the Saka at the River Jaxartes, now known as the Syr Darya River.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Persian_Gate
object: The Battle of the Persian Gate was a military conflict between a Persian force, commanded by the satrap of Persis, Ariobarzanes, and the invading Hellenic League, commanded by Alexander the Great.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Before continuing his pursuit of Darius III, who has retreated into Bactria, Alexander assembles all the Persian treasure and entrusts it to Harpalus, who is to hold it at Ecbatana as chief treasurer. Parmenion is also left behind in Media to manage communications between Alexander and the rest of his rapidly growing lands.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Uxian_Defile
object: The Battle of Uxian Defile was fought by Alexander the Great against the Uxian tribe of the Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Megalopolis
object: Alexander's regent in Macedonia, Antipater, makes peace with the Thracians (with whom he has been warring) and then marches south with a large force of over 40,000 men. He wins a hard-fought Battle of Megalopolis in Arcadia against Agis III of Sparta and his Greek mercenaries. Agis III is killed, and Spartan resistance is broken.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Gaugamela
object: The Battle of Gaugamela, also called the Battle of Arbela, took place in 331 BC between the forces of the Army of Macedon under Alexander the Great and the Persian Army under King Darius III.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Uxian_Defile
object: The Battle of Uxian Defile was fought by Alexander the Great against the Uxian tribe of the Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Tyre_(332_BC)
object: The siege of Tyre was orchestrated by Alexander the Great in 332 BC during his campaigns against the Persians.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander's regent Antipater leads the Macedonians to victory over King Agis III in the Battle of Megalopolis.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Gaza
object: The siege of Gaza, as part of the Wars of Alexander the Great, took place in October of 332 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander is victorious in the Battle of Gaugamela (near ancient Ninevah) over the Persian King Darius III. Alexander pursues the defeated Persian forces to Arbela, Darius moves his Bactrian cavalry and Greek mercenaries into Media.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Gaza
object: The siege of Gaza, as part of the Wars of Alexander the Great, took place in October of 332 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander the Great occupies Damascus and, after a siege lasting seven months, destroys Tyre during which there is great carnage and the sale of the women and children into slavery.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: The Battle of Issus occurred in southern Anatolia, on 5 November 333 BC between the Hellenic League led by Alexander the Great and the Achaemenid Empire, led by Darius III.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: The Battle of Issus occurred in southern Anatolia, on 5 November 333 BC between the Hellenic League led by Alexander the Great and the Achaemenid Empire, led by Darius III.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Halicarnassus
object: The siege of Halicarnassus was fought between Alexander the Great and the Achaemenid Persian Empire in 334 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: King Darius III of Persia executes Charidemus, a Greek mercenary leader living in exile in Persia, for criticising preparations taken for the Battle of Issus.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: After taking Byblos and Sidon, Alexander lays siege to Tyre.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Granicus
object: The Battle of the Granicus in May 334 BC was the first of three major battles fought between Alexander the Great of Macedon and the Persian Achaemenid Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander has a great victory over the Persians in the Battle of the Issus River in Cilicia, but the Persian Emperor Darius III escapes. Darius leaves behind his wife, his two daughters, his mother Sisygambis, and much of his personal treasure. Darius' family is captured by Alexander and well treated.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Miletus
object: The siege of Miletus was Alexander the Great's first siege and naval encounter with the Achaemenid Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Granicus
object: The Battle of the Granicus in May 334 BC was the first of three major battles fought between Alexander the Great of Macedon and the Persian Achaemenid Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Alexander's_Balkan_campaign
object: The Balkan campaign of Alexander the Great took place in 335 BC, against a number of rebellious vassals of the Macedonian kingdom.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Thebes
object: The Battle of Thebes was a battle that took place between Alexander the Great and the Greek city-state of Thebes in 335 BC immediately outside of and in the city proper in Boeotia.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Pelium
object: The siege of Pelium was undertaken by Alexander the Great against the Illyrian tribes of what is modern-day Albania.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_Alexander_the_Great
object: Alexander wins a major victory against the Persians commanded by the Greek mercenary Memnon of Rhodes, in the Battle of the Granicus near the Sea of Marmara. A large number of King Darius III's Greek mercenaries are massacred, but 2,000 survivors are sent back to Macedonia in chains.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Thebes
object: The Battle of Thebes was a battle that took place between Alexander the Great and the Greek city-state of Thebes in 335 BC immediately outside of and in the city proper in Boeotia.

object: This Battle of Megiddo is recorded as having taken place in 609 BC when Pharaoh Necho II of Egypt led his army to Carchemish to join with his allies, the fading Neo-Assyrian Empire, against the surging Neo-Babylonian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Megiddo_(609_BC)
object: Battle of Megiddo—King Josiah is killed fighting against Necho II, who was on his way to aid the Assyrian state.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Hellenistic period ends (or AD 14 by some scholars).

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Autumn – The Donations of Alexandria: Antony distributes the eastern kingdoms as a gift to the children of Cleopatra VII of Egypt; he declares Caesarion, Caesar's illegitimate son, as co-ruler of Egypt and Cyprus. Alexander Helios receives Armenia and Media; to Cleopatra Selene he gives the kingdoms of Cyrenaica and Libya. His youngest son Ptolemy Philadelphus receives the Egyptian possessions in Phoenicia, Syria and Cilicia. Antony establishes Cleopatra as a Hellenistic monarch at Alexandria and gives her the title of "Queen of Kings".

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Han expeditionary force under Li Guangli conquers the state of Luntai. Li Guangli then besieges Alexandria Eschate, the capital of Dayuan in the Hellenistic Ferghana Valley, despite having lost half his army to hunger, thirst and battle by the time he reached the city. The Dayuan are defeated in battle, and after losing their outer wall and their best general Jianmi in battle, the nobles kill King Wugua and offer terms of peace to Li Guangli, who accepts. The Han receive some of the prized horses of Dayuan and Li Guangli appoints Mocai as the new king.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: With Carthage and Greece conquered, Rome becomes the sole superpower in the Mediterranean world, a position it would hold for the next five hundred years.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: At Polybius' request, Scipio Aemilianus manages to gain the support of the Roman statesman Cato the Elder (whose son has married Scipio's sister Aemilia) for a proposal to release (and return to Greece) the 300 Achaean internees who are still being held without trial after being deported to Rome in 167 BC.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: King Eupator of Bosphorus pays tribute to Rome, due to the threat posed by the Alani.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: With the restoration of peace in Judea, an internal struggle breaks out between the supporters of Judas Maccabeus and the Hellenic party. The influence of the Hellenic Party all but collapses in the wake of the Seleucid defeat.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: With the aid of the Greek statesman and historian Polybius, the son of the former Seleucid king Seleucus IV Philopator, Demetrius escapes from Rome, where he has been held as a hostage for many years, and returns to Syria to claim the throne from his nephew Antiochus V. In the resulting dispute, Antiochus V and his regent, Lysias, are overthrown and put to death. Demetrius then establishes himself on the Seleucid throne.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Private documents collected by the Romans when they capture Perseus of Macedon incriminate political leaders of the Achaean League. Many influential Greeks are deported to Rome.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Parthians capture the key central Asian city of Herat. This victory effectively chokes off the movement of trade along the Silk Road to China and means that the Hellenic kingdom of Bactria is doomed.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: King Perseus asks the Seleucid King Antiochus IV to join forces with him against the danger that Rome presents to all of the Hellenic monarchs. Antiochus IV does not respond.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: With concerns rising in Rome over whether Philip V of Macedon is preparing for a new war with the Romans, Appius Claudius Pulcher is sent at the head of an embassy into Macedonia and Greece to observe Philip's activities.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The leader of the Achaean League, Philopoemen, enters northern Laconia with his army and a group of Spartan exiles. His army demolishes the wall that the former tyrant of Sparta, Nabis, has built around Sparta. Philopoemen then restores Spartan citizenship to the exiles and abolishes Spartan law, introducing Achaean law in its place. Sparta's role as a major power in Greece ends, while the Achaean League becomes the dominant power throughout the Peloponnese.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Eumenes II of Pergamum appeals to Rome for help against the Seleucid king Antiochus III who is threatening to conquer Greece. The Roman pro-consul Titus Quinctius Flamininus supports the Roman championship of Greek autonomy in Anatolia.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: After checking the ambitions of the Spartan tyrant, Nabis, the Roman forces under pro-consul Titus Quinctius Flamininus finally withdraw from Greece.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Alexander the Great, head from a Hellenistic copy of a statue, possibly after a 4th century BC original by Lysippos is made. It is now kept at the Archeological Museum in Istanbul, Turkey.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Hannibal erects a bilingual Punic/Greek inscription describing his accomplishments in the temple of Juno Lacinia near Crotone.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Roman historian Quintus Fabius Pictor is sent to Delphi in Greece to consult the Oracle for advice about what Rome should do after its defeat in the Battle of Cannae.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Together with fellow Illyrian, Scerdilaidas, Demetrius of Pharos attacks Illyrian cities under Roman protection and leads a piratical squadron into Greek waters. They unsuccessfully attack Pylos, an Achaean town on the Messenian coast, in the Peloponnesus of Greece.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Almost all of Greece falls under Macedonian suzerainty after Antigonus III re-establishes the Hellenic Alliance as a confederacy of leagues, with himself as president.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The first Latin tragedy by Livius Andronicus, Achilles, is first produced.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Hellenistic period Mathematician Eratosthenes estimates the Earth's circumference to be 252,000 stadia, a figure between 2%-20% off modern measurements.</onlyinclude>

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Without a declaration of hostilities, Greek statesman, Aratus of Sicyon, who has gradually built up the Achaean League into a major power in Greece, makes a surprise attack on Corinth and forces the withdrawal of the Macedonian occupation troops. Megara, Troezen, and Epidaurus also desert the Macedonian King Antigonus II.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: With the restoration of the territories captured by Pyrrhus, and with grateful allies in Sparta and Argos, and garrisons in Corinth and other Greek key cities, Antigonus II securely controls Macedonia and the other states of Greece. Antigonus becomes the chief of the Thessalian League and is on good terms with neighbouring Illyria and Thrace. He secures his position in central and south Greece by keeping Macedonian occupation forces in the cities of Corinth, Chalcis on the island of Euboea, and Demetrias in Thessaly, the three "shackles" of Hellas.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: As part of a strategy of clemency, Aurelian spares Tyana after capturing the city. This strategy encourages units under Zenobia to defect to Aurelian.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Following the Battle of Corupedium, Lysimachus' widow, Arsinoe, flees to Cassandrea, a city in northern Greece, where she marries her half-brother Ptolemy Keraunos. This proves to be a serious misjudgement, as Ptolemy Keraunus promptly kills two of her sons, though the third is able to escape. Arsinoe flees again, this time to Alexandria in Egypt.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Although he has only a few bases in Greece, Antigonus II Gonatas lays claim to Macedonia. His claim is disputed by Antiochus I.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: As Demetrius Poliorcetes and his army are chased across Asia Minor to the Taurus Mountains by the armies of Lysimachus and Seleucus, in Greece his son Antigonus meets with success. Ptolemy's fleet is driven off and Athens surrenders to Antigonus.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Demetrius Poliorcetes returns to Greece with the aim of becoming master of Macedonia. While Demetrius is in Greece, Lysimachus seizes his possessions in Asia Minor.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: As Cassander fights to retain control over central Greece, Antigonus promises freedom to the Greek cities in a bid to gain support from them against Cassander.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Cassander, who has allied himself with Ptolemy and Antigonus, declares war on the regent, Polyperchon. Most of the Greek states support him, including Athens. Cassander further effects an alliance with Eurydice, the ambitious wife of King Philip III Arrhidaeus of Macedon.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: In Classical antiquity, the Hellenistic period covers the time in Mediterranean history after Classical Greece, between the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC and the emergence of the Roman Empire, as signified by the Battle of Actium in 31 BC and the conquest of Ptolemaic Egypt the following year.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The ancient Greek city of Helike is destroyed by a massive earthquake and tsunami.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greeks found the colony of Pharos at the site of today’s Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, defeating Iadasinoi warriors brought in for its defense.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek philosopher Socrates is sentenced to death by Athenian authorities, condemned for impiety and the corruption of youth. He refuses to flee into exile and dies by drinking hemlock.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The catapult is invented by Greek engineers.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Mature classical period of sculpture ends in Ancient Greece and is succeeded by the fourth-century (Late Classical) period (approximate date).

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Dionysius the Elder ruthlessly consolidates and expands his power. He builds a wall around Syracuse and fortifies Epipolae. The Greek citizens of Naxos, Catana, and Leontini are removed from their cities; many of them are enslaved and their homes are given to Sicilian and Italian mercenaries. Dionysius prepares his army to fight against Carthage, which now occupies western and southern Sicily.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The city of Cumae, the most northerly of the Greek colonies in Italy, falls to the Samnites.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: What some historians call the Rich style begins in Greece.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek colony of Cumae in Italy falls to the Samnites, who begin to take control of the Campanian plain.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek philosopher Empedocles distinguishes the four elements - earth, fire, water, and air - that he claims all substances are made of. He explains the development of the universe by the forces of attraction and repulsion known as Love and Strife.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek colony of Heraclea in Southern Italy is founded by colonists from Tarentum and Thurii.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek playwright, Euripides, wins his first victory in a dramatic festival.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Achaeus of Eretria, a Greek playwright, produces his first play.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Hostilities between Segesta and Selinunte, two Greek cities on Sicily, take place over access to the Tyrrhenian Sea.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Greek colony of Taras, in Magna Graecia, is defeated by the native population of Apulia. As a result, the Tarentine monarchy falls, with the installation of a democracy.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Spartan co-ruler Leotychides and the Athenian leader Themistocles lead a fleet and army to reoccupy northern Greece and to punish the aristocratic family of the Aleuads for having aided the Persians. Leotychides is caught accepting a bribe during the operations in Thessaly.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Despite Spartan opposition, Athens works on refortifying and rebuilding after the Persian destruction of the city in 479.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: King Alexander I of Macedon is obliged to accompany Xerxes in a campaign through Greece, though he secretly aids the Greek allies. With Xerxes' apparent acquiescence, Alexander seizes the Greek colony of Pydna and advances his frontiers eastward to the Strymon, taking in Crestonia and Bisaltia, along with the rich silver deposits of Mount Dysorus.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Breaking through the pass at Thermopylae from Macedonia into Greece, the Persians occupy Attica.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The Persian King Xerxes I arrives at Sardis and begins to build up his great army and navy for the invasion of Greece. Egypt contributes 481 ships.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The first expedition of King Darius I of Persia against Greece commences under the leadership of his son-in-law and general, Mardonius. Darius sends Mardonius to succeed his satrap (governor) in Ionia, Artaphernes, with a special commission to attack Athens and Eretria.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Greek city of Elea of southern Italy is founded (approximate date)

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Orientalizing period of vases ends in Ancient Greece (approximate date).

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Greece's games of the 25th Olympiad is held at Olympia with the first equestrian event. A four-horse chariot race is run at the nearby hippodrome, slaves driving the chariots in a fierce competition that not infrequently ends in death.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Greek colonization of the Mediterranean in the next two centuries will be motivated primarily by a need to find new food sources as Greece's population expands. The barren and rocky soil of the Greek Peninsula is inadequate to meet the people's alimentary needs (approximate date).

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Ancient Greece was a northeastern Mediterranean civilization, existing from the Greek Dark Ages of the 12th–9th centuries BC to the end of classical antiquity, that comprised a loose collection of culturally and linguistically related city-states and other territories.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: The classical statue of Laocoön and His Sons is unearthed in Rome. On the recommendation of Giuliano da Sangallo and Michelangelo, Pope Julius II purchases it, and places it on public display in the Vatican a month later.

subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek
object: Channel 4 debuts the three-part dramatised documentary Sex BC, is about the ancient history of human sexuality in which prehistoric peoples throughout civilisation from different periods include the Stone Age, Greece and Egypt within the subject material being handled in an intelligent and educational fashion. The series continues on 12 August.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: The Hellenistic period ends (or AD 14 by some scholars).

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: Autumn – The Donations of Alexandria: Antony distributes the eastern kingdoms as a gift to the children of Cleopatra VII of Egypt; he declares Caesarion, Caesar's illegitimate son, as co-ruler of Egypt and Cyprus. Alexander Helios receives Armenia and Media; to Cleopatra Selene he gives the kingdoms of Cyrenaica and Libya. His youngest son Ptolemy Philadelphus receives the Egyptian possessions in Phoenicia, Syria and Cilicia. Antony establishes Cleopatra as a Hellenistic monarch at Alexandria and gives her the title of "Queen of Kings".

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: The Han expeditionary force under Li Guangli conquers the state of Luntai. Li Guangli then besieges Alexandria Eschate, the capital of Dayuan in the Hellenistic Ferghana Valley, despite having lost half his army to hunger, thirst and battle by the time he reached the city. The Dayuan are defeated in battle, and after losing their outer wall and their best general Jianmi in battle, the nobles kill King Wugua and offer terms of peace to Li Guangli, who accepts. The Han receive some of the prized horses of Dayuan and Li Guangli appoints Mocai as the new king.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: With the restoration of peace in Judea, an internal struggle breaks out between the supporters of Judas Maccabeus and the Hellenic party. The influence of the Hellenic Party all but collapses in the wake of the Seleucid defeat.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: The Parthians capture the key central Asian city of Herat. This victory effectively chokes off the movement of trade along the Silk Road to China and means that the Hellenic kingdom of Bactria is doomed.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: King Perseus asks the Seleucid King Antiochus IV to join forces with him against the danger that Rome presents to all of the Hellenic monarchs. Antiochus IV does not respond.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: Alexander the Great, head from a Hellenistic copy of a statue, possibly after a 4th century BC original by Lysippos is made. It is now kept at the Archeological Museum in Istanbul, Turkey.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: The Hellenistic period Mathematician Eratosthenes estimates the Earth's circumference to be 252,000 stadia, a figure between 2%-20% off modern measurements.</onlyinclude>

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: As part of a strategy of clemency, Aurelian spares Tyana after capturing the city. This strategy encourages units under Zenobia to defect to Aurelian.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Hellenistic_period
object: In Classical antiquity, the Hellenistic period covers the time in Mediterranean history after Classical Greece, between the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC and the emergence of the Roman Empire, as signified by the Battle of Actium in 31 BC and the conquest of Ptolemaic Egypt the following year.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burial
object: Emperor Kōtoku makes a decree about the policies of building tombs. He discontinues the old customs of sacrificing people in honor of a dead man, and forbids ill-considered rituals about purgation.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burial
object: H U.S. President Zachary Taylor, who died 141 years earlier in 1850, is exhumed to discover whether or not his death was caused by arsenic poisoning, instead of acute gastrointestinal illness; no trace of arsenic is found.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Burial
object: Washington becomes the first state to legalize human composting, the right to allow people to have their body turned into soil after death. The process is seen as an alternative to traditional cremations and burials.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Corupedium
object: The Battle of Corupedium, also called Koroupedion, Corupedion or Curupedion was the last battle between the Diadochi, the rival successors to Alexander the Great.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: Pyrrhus, the King of Epirus, is taken as a hostage to Egypt after the Battle of Ipsus and makes a diplomatic marriage with the princess Antigone, daughter of Ptolemy and Berenice.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_the_Diadochi
object: The Siege of Rhodes ends after a year.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Rhodes_(305–304_BC)
object: The siege of Rhodes in 305–304 BC was one of the most notable sieges of antiquity, when Demetrius Poliorcetes, son of Antigonus I, besieged Rhodes in an attempt to make it abandon its neutrality and end its close relationship with Ptolemy I.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Salamis_(306_BC)
object: The naval Battle of Salamis in 306 BC took place off Salamis, Cyprus between the fleets of Ptolemy I of Egypt and Antigonus I Monophthalmus, two of the Diadochi, the generals who, after the death of Alexander the Great, fought each other for control of his empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_the_Diadochi
object: Demetrius Poliorcetes lands on Cyprus and besieges Menelaus, brother of Egypt's ruler, Ptolemy I Soter, at Salamis. Ptolemy Soter, coming to his brother's aid, is decisively defeated in the Battle of Salamis. The battle completely destroys the naval power of Egypt and results in the capture of Cyprus by Demetrius. This gives Demetrius' father, Antigonus I Monophthalmus, control of the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_25_of_Abu
object: The battle of the 25 of Abu of 309 B.C. in an unknown location between Babylon and Susa, was the decisive and final clash of the Babylonian war.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Third_Siege_of_Babylon_(309_BC)
object: The Third siege of Babylon took place during Antigonus's expedition to the Seleucid domain in the context of the Babylonian war.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Second_Siege_of_Babylon_(310_BC)
object: The Second siege of Babylon took place during the Babylonian War in 310 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Babylonian_War
object: The Babylonian War was a conflict fought between 311–309 BC between Antigonus I Monophthalmus and Seleucus I Nicator, ending in a victory for Seleucus.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/First_Siege_of_Babylon_(311_BC)
object: The First Siege of Babylon was a successful siege of one of its citadels, loyal to Antigonus, by forces under Seleucus in 311 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Antigonid–Nabataean_confrontations
object: The Antigonid–Nabataean confrontations were three confrontations initiated by Greek general Antigonus I against the Arab Nabataeans in 312 BC.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Gaza_(312_BC)
object: The Battle of Gaza was a battle of the Third war of the Diadochi between Ptolemy against Demetrius .

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Partition_of_Triparadisus
object: The Partition of Triparadisus was a power-sharing agreement passed at Triparadisus in 321 BC between the generals of Alexander the Great, in which they named a new regent and arranged the repartition of the satrapies of Alexander's empire among themselves.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Hellespont_(321_BC)
object: The Battle of the Hellespont took place in 321 BC between the armies of Craterus and Neoptolemus against Eumenes.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Lamia
object: The siege of Lamia occurred in 322 BC between the Macedonians led by Antipater and a coalition of armies mostly from central Greece led by Leosthenes.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Defeat_of_Leonnatus_by_Antiphilus
object: The defeat of Leonnatus by Antiphilus occurred during the Lamian War fought between the Greek allies who had rebelled against the Macedonian Empire, and Leonnatus, the Macedonian satrap of Phrygia, who had come to aid the regent Antipater, who was being besieged by the Greeks in Lamia.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Echinades_(322_BC)
object: The Battle of the Echinades was one of the naval battles of the Lamian War, fought between the Macedonian navy under Cleitus the White and the Athenian navy.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_the_Diadochi
object: The Wars of the Diadochi, or Wars of Alexander's Successors, were a series of conflicts that were fought between the generals of Alexander the Great, known as the Diadochi, over who would rule his empire following his death.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Crannon
object: The Battle of Crannon, fought between the Macedonian forces of Antipater and Craterus and the forces of a coalition of cities including Athens and the Aetolian League, was the decisive battle of the Lamian War.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Plataea_(323_BC)
object: The Battle of Plataea was fought during 323 BC between the Athenian and Boeotian armies during the Lamian War.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_the_Diadochi
object: The Athenian orator and diplomat, Demades, regains his citizenship so that he and Phocion can negotiate a peace with Antipater, thus concluding the Lamian War. Before setting out he persuades the citizens of Athens to pass the death sentence upon Demosthenes and his followers (including Hypereides, leader of the Athenian patriotic party). Demades' embassy results in a peace disadvantageous to the Athenians, with the Athenians forced to accept the occupation of Athens' port, Piraeus, by the Macedonians.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Thermopylae_(323_BC)
object: The Battle of Thermopylae was fought in 323 BC between the Macedonians and a coalition of armies including Athens and the Aetolian League in the pass of Thermopylae during the Lamian War.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Lamian_War
object: The Lamian War, or the Hellenic War was fought by a coalition of cities including Athens and the Aetolian League against Macedon and its ally Boeotia.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Wars_of_the_Diadochi
object: Following Alexander the Great's death, the Athenians recall Demosthenes from exile and provide the money to pay his fine.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: The Battle of Issus occurred in southern Anatolia, on 5 November 333 BC between the Hellenic League led by Alexander the Great and the Achaemenid Empire, led by Darius III.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: The Battle of Issus occurred in southern Anatolia, on 5 November 333 BC between the Hellenic League led by Alexander the Great and the Achaemenid Empire, led by Darius III.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: King Darius III of Persia executes Charidemus, a Greek mercenary leader living in exile in Persia, for criticising preparations taken for the Battle of Issus.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: Alexander has a great victory over the Persians in the Battle of the Issus River in Cilicia, but the Persian Emperor Darius III escapes. Darius leaves behind his wife, his two daughters, his mother Sisygambis, and much of his personal treasure. Darius' family is captured by Alexander and well treated.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Chaeronea_(338_BC)
object: The Battle of Chaeronea was fought in 338 BC, near the city of Chaeronea in Boeotia, between Macedonia under Philip II and an alliance of city-states led by Athens and Thebes.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Chaeronea_(338_BC)
object: The Battle of Chaeronea was fought in 338 BC, near the city of Chaeronea in Boeotia, between Macedonia under Philip II and an alliance of city-states led by Athens and Thebes.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Chaeronea_(338_BC)
object: Philip II of Macedon defeats the Athenians and Thebans in the Battle of Chaeronea in western Boeotia. His son, Alexander, commands the left wing of the Macedonian army during the battle. In victory, Philip II is harsh on Thebes, but merciful on Athens, thanks to the efforts of the Athenian orator and diplomat, Demades, who helps negotiate a peace agreement between Macedonia and Athens.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Alexandria_(30_BC)
object: The Battle of Alexandria was fought on July 1 to July 30, 30 BC between the forces of Octavian and Mark Antony during the last war of the Roman Republic.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Alexandria_(30_BC)
object: The Battle of Alexandria was fought on July 1 to July 30, 30 BC between the forces of Octavian and Mark Antony during the last war of the Roman Republic.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/War_of_Actium
object: Mark Antony achieves a minor victory over Octavian's forces, but most of his army subsequently deserts, leading to his suicide.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Actium
object: The Battle of Actium was a naval battle fought between a maritime fleet of Octavian led by Marcus Agrippa and the combined fleets of both Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII Philopator.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/War_of_Actium
object: Battle of Actium: Off the western coast of Greece, Octavian Caesar defeats naval forces under Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/War_of_Actium
object: Spring – Final War of the Roman Republic: Mark Antony transfers his headquarters from Samos to Athens, where he assembles a fleet of 500 combat vessels and 300 transport ships, crewed by 150,000 men.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/War_of_Actium
object: Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus and Gaius Sosius become consuls of Rome.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Actium

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Ancient_Greek_religion
object: The tragedian Agathon wins first prize at the Lenaia.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Ancient_Greek_religion
object: Aristophanes' play The Wasps is performed.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Ancient_Greek_religion
object: Aristophanes' play The Acharnians is performed. Produced by Callistratus, it wins Aristophanes a first prize at the Lenaea.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Lenaia

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Byzantine expeditionary force under Justin retakes Archaeopolis (modern Georgia), and routs the Persian army.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: The Avars arrive in the northern region of the Caucasus, between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. They send envoys to the Byzantines in Lazica (modern Georgia). Like the Huns, the Avars are the former elite of a central Asian federation, which has been forced to flee westwards.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Byzantine–Sasanian_War_of_572–591
object: The Byzantine–Sasanian War of 572–591 was a war fought between the Sasanian Empire of Persia and the Eastern Roman Empire, termed by modern historians as the Byzantine Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: Emperor Justin II refuses to pay the annual tribute to Khosrau I, putting an end to the 50-year peace treaty established ten years earlier. The Armenians are considered allies to the Byzantine Empire, and Justin sends a Byzantine army into Persian territory, besieging the fortress city of Nisibis (modern Turkey).

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Dara_(573)
object: The siege of Dara was raised by the Sasanian king Khosrow I in 573 during the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 572–591.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Nisibis_(252)
object: The siege of Nisibis took place in 573 when the Eastern Roman Empire, under Emperor Justin II, besieged the Sasanian city of Nisibis.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Byzantine army under command of Maurice drives the Persians from Cappodocia (modern Turkey), and strengthens the Byzantine position in Caucasian Albania.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Persian army under King Khosrau I breaks through the Caucasus into Anatolia (modern Turkey). They attack the cities of Theodosiopolis and Caesarea, but are thwarted. Khosrau is forced to retreat and sacks Sebasteia. On the way home, he is intercepted by a Byzantine force under Justinian (magister militum of the East), and severely defeated near Melitene. The royal baggage is captured, and many Persians drown, while escaping across the Euphrates.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Byzantine expeditionary force under command of Justinian (magister militum) invades Caucasian Albania, launching raids across the Caspian Sea against the Persians.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: Khosrau I dies after a 48-year reign, during which he has extended his realm from the River Oxus to the Red Sea. He is succeeded by his son Hormizd IV, who becomes king of the Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: King Khosrau I seeks peace, but dies before an agreement can be reached. The Mesopotamian front becomes stalemated, and Maurice (magister militum of the East) fortifies the borders in Armenia and Syria.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Byzantine army commanded by Maurice, and supported by Ghassanid forces under King Al-Mundhir III, fails to capture the Persian capital, Ctesiphon, along the Euphrates.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Solachon
object: A Byzantine army under command of Philippicus defeats the Sassanid Persians, near Dara.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: Unpaid Byzantine troops mutiny against Priscus (magister militum per Orientem). King Hormizd IV begins a Persian offensive, but is defeated at Martyropolis (modern Turkey).

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Martyropolis_(588)
object: The Battle of Martyropolis was fought in summer 588 near Martyropolis between an East Roman and a Sassanid Persian army, and resulted in a Byzantine victory.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: A Persian army of about 40,000 men under King Bahrām VI is defeated, in the lowlands near Ganzak (northwestern Iran), by the Byzantines. Bahrām flees to seek refuge with the Turks in Central Asia, and settles in Fergana. However, after some time, he is murdered by a hired assassin of Khosrau II.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_the_Blarathon
object: The Battle of the Blarathon, also known as the Battle of Ganzak, was fought in 591 near Ganzak between a combined Byzantine–Persian force and a Persian army led by the usurper Bahram Chobin.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Byzantine–Sasanian_War_of_602–628
object: The Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628 was the final and most devastating of the series of wars fought between the Byzantine / Roman Empire and the Sasanian Empire of Iran.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: King Khosrau II invades Armenia, and raids deep into Anatolia through the Byzantine provinces of Cappadocia, Phrygia, Galatia, and Bithynia.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Antioch_(613)
object: Heraclius mobilises a Byzantine expeditionary force to Antioch (Syria), but is completely defeated outside the city by the Persians. Shahin Vahmanzadegan makes further inroads into Central and Western Anatolia. In Syria, Shahrbaraz captures the cities of Damascus, Apamea and Emesa.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Jewish_revolt_against_Heraclius
object: The Jewish revolt against Heraclius was part of the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628 and is considered the last serious Jewish attempt to gain autonomy in Palaestina Prima prior to modern times.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem
object: The Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem occurred after a brief siege of the city by the Sasanian military in 614 CE, and was a significant event in the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628 that took place after the Sasanian king Khosrow II appointed his spahbod, Shahrbaraz, to take control of the Byzantine-ruled areas of the Near East for the Sasanian Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem
object: The Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem occurred after a brief siege of the city by the Sasanian military in 614 CE, and was a significant event in the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628 that took place after the Sasanian king Khosrow II appointed his spahbod, Shahrbaraz, to take control of the Byzantine-ruled areas of the Near East for the Sasanian Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem
object: The Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem occurred after a brief siege of the city by the Sasanian military in 614 CE, and was a significant event in the Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628 that took place after the Sasanian king Khosrow II appointed his spahbod, Shahrbaraz, to take control of the Byzantine-ruled areas of the Near East for the Sasanian Persian Empire.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: The Jews of Jerusalem gain complete control over the city; much of Judea and Galilee becomes an autonomous Jewish province of the Persian Empire. The Jewish Temple is rebuilt by Nehemiah ben Hushiel (exilarch of Jerusalem), who establishes a High Priesthood.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Heraclius'_campaign_of_622
object: Heraclius defeats the Persian forces under Shahrbaraz in Cappadocia. He recaptures Anatolia, but returns to Constantinople to deal with the threat posed to his Balkan domains by the Avars, and puts the Byzantine army into winter quarters in Pontus.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: Heraclius is victorious in a Byzantine assault river crossing. The reinforced Persians under Shahrbaraz are defeated along the Sarus River, near Adana (modern Turkey). Heraclius recaptures Cappadocia and Pontus, and returns to Trapezus to spend the winter. Shahrbaraz retreats in good order, and is able to continue his advance through Asia Minor towards Constantinople.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Sarus
object: The Battle of Sarus was a battle fought in April 625 between the Byzantine army, led by Emperor Heraclius, and the Persian general Shahrbaraz.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Constantinople_(626)
object: The siege of Constantinople in 626 by the Sassanid Persians and Avars, aided by large numbers of allied Slavs, ended in a strategic victory for the Byzantines.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Siege_of_Constantinople_(626)
object: The siege of Constantinople in 626 by the Sassanid Persians and Avars, aided by large numbers of allied Slavs, ended in a strategic victory for the Byzantines.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: The Avar and Slav armies leave the siege of Constantinople.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Third_Perso-Turkic_War
object: The Third Perso-Turkic War was the third and final conflict between the Sassanian Empire and the Western Turkic Khaganate.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Battle_of_Nineveh_(627)
object: The Battle of Nineveh was the climactic battle of the Byzantine-Sassanid War of 602–628.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: The Western Göktürks, under their leader Tong Yabghu Qaghan, plunder Tbilisi (modern Georgia). The Persian defenders are executed or mutilated; Tong Yabghu appoints governors (tuduns) to manage various tribes under his overlordship.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: The Roman–Persian Wars, also known as the Roman–Iranian Wars, were a series of conflicts between states of the Greco-Roman world and two successive Iranian empires: the Parthian and the Sasanian.

subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Roman–Persian_Wars
object: Emperor Heraclius enters Constantinople in triumph after his victory over the Persian Empire.
